The reason is, that the Superficies of Such Plates are not even 
but haue many cavities & Swellings, wch, how Shallow Soeuer,
do a little vary the thicknes of the Plate: And by the Seu[er]all
Sides of those cavities there must be produced waues in Seuerall 
postures of the Prism. Now though it be but some very small 
& narrow partes of the Glasse, by which these waues for the most 
part are caused, yet they may Seeme to extend themselues ouer 
the whole Glasse, because from the narrowest of those parts 
there are colours of Seu[er]all Orders confusedly reflected, wch by 
refraction of the Prism are unfolded & dispersed to Seu[er]all
places, So as to constitute Soe many Severall waues as there 
were divers Orders of the colours promiscuously reflected from 
that part of the glasse.
These are the Principall Phaenomena of thin plates or 
Bubbles whose Explications depend on the Properties of Light 
that I haue heretofore delivered: And these you see doe 
necessarily follow from them & agree with them even to their 
very least circumstances; and not onely Soe but doe very much 
tend to their proof. Thus by the 24th Observac[i]on it appears 
that the rayes of Seu[er]all colours, made as well by thin plates or 
Bubbles as by the refractions of a Prisme, haue Seu[er]all Degrees 
of refrangibi<s>l<\s>lity, whereby those of each Order, which at their 
reflection from the Plate or Bubble are intermixed with those 
of other Orders, are Separated from them by refraction, and 
associated together So as to become visible by themselues like 
arcs of Circles. For, if the rayes were all alike refrangible, tis 
impossible, that the whitenes, which to the naked Sense appears 
uniform, Should by refraction haue its parts transposed and 
ranged into those black & white Arcs.
It appears also that the unequall refractions of difform 
Rayes proceed not from any contingent irregularities Such as 
are veines, an uneven polish, or fortuitous position of the pores of 
Glasse, unequall motions in the Air or <s>either<\s> Aether Spreading, breaking 
or dividing the Same ray into many divergeing parts, or the like.
For, admitting any Such irregularities, it would be impossible 
for refractions to render those Rings Soe very distinct and 
well defined, as they doe in the 24th Observac[i]on. It is 
necessary therefore that every ray have its proper & constant 
degree of refrangibi<s>l<\s>lity connate with it, according to wch its
